metadata.title: Nonlinear vibrations of pre- and post-buckled lipid supramolecular micro/nano-tubules via nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory

sections.text:
1
The unique geometry with high surface ratio makes lipid micro/nano-tubules as an excellent selfassembled supramolecular structure in various biological applications such as controllable release systems and drug delivery. In the present study, the size-dependent nonlinear vibrations of axially loaded lipid micro/nano tubules associated with the both prebuckling and postbuckling domains are explored comprehensively. To accomplish this purpose, the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity including simultaneously two entirely different features of size dependency is utilized within the framework of the third-order shear deformable beam model. With the aid of Hamilton's principle, the non-classical governing differential equations of motion are established incorporating the nonlinear prebuckling deformations and the large postbuckling deflections. At the end, the Galerkin method in conjunction with an improved perturbation technique is employed to initiate explicit analytical expressions for nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear frequency of pre- and post-buckled lipid micro/nano-tubules. It is seen that by taking the nonlocal size effect into consideration, the influence of geometrical parameters of the lipid micro/nano-tubule on the nonlinear vibration characteristics within the both prebuckling and postbuckling domains decreases and the frequency-deflection curves are more close to each other. However, the strain gradient size dependency has an opposite effect and leads to increase the gap between the frequency-deflection curves of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubules with different geometrical parameters.
Keywords: Nanotechnology; Biomechanics; Small scale effect; Self-assembly molecular structure; Nonlinear dynamics.
* Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 21 66405844, Fax: +98 21 66419736. E-mail address: sahmani@aut.ac.ir (S. Sahmani).
2

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
After discovering lipid micro/nano-tubules made of crystalline bilayer membranes by Yamada et al. (1984), it has been attracted much attention because of its outstanding physical and chemical functionalities. In order to release bioactive agents, Meilander et al. (2001) introduced a lipid-based micro/nano-tubular drug delivery vehicle. Meilander et al. (2003) also used lipid micro/nano-tubule to design sustained delivery systems to release functional DNA. Kameta et al. (2005) made known the lipid tubules as a supramolecular nanotube host with cationic inner surfaces to encapsulate efficiently anionic nanomaterials. Kameta et al. (2008) also utilized lipid micro/nano-tubules to build sensor with capability to detect encapsulation and transportation as well as the stability of green fluorescent protein.
In lipid-based micro/nano-tubular drug delivery systems, the micro/nano-tubule is under different loading conditions as well as mechanical vibrations. As a result, in order to design more efficient and accurate systems, it is essential to study the mechanical behavior of a lipid supramolecular micro/nano-tubule. Some investigations have been performed to report the biological significance for mechanical responses of lipid micro/nano-tubules. For instance, Rosso and Virga (1998) presented an exact solution for statics and an approximate solution for detachment dynamics of adhering lipid micro/nano-tubules. Rosso and Virga (1998) also derived the equilibrium condition for an adhesion by curvature of lipid micro/nano-tubules. Zhao et al. (2007) examined the buckling deformation of lipid micro/nano-tubules trapped inside liquid droplets on glass substrate. Li (2008) described a mechanics model model for buckling behavior of microtubules in living cells including the effects of surrounding filament network and the cytosol. Zhao et al. (2009) also anticipated the instability characteristic of multibilayer lipid micro/nano-tubules under local radial atomic force. Shen (2011a) developed nonlocal beam model for analysis of nonlinear mechanical behaviors of lipid micro/nano-tubules. Daneshmand et al. (2011) explored the general wave propagation behavior in protein microtubules using a first-order shear deformable shell theory for orthotropic materials. Shen (2011b) presented size-dependent nonlinear bending and nonlinear vibration analyses for lipid microtubules on the basis of a developed nonlocal beam model. Stepanyants et al. (2012) proposed a novel method to measure of lipid micro/nano-tubule radii. Karimi Zeverdejani and Tadi Beni (2013) investigated the free vibration response of protein microtubules embedded in the cytoplasm by incorporating the modified strain gradient elasticity theory into the Euler-Bernoulli beam theory. Ghorbanpour Arani et al. (2015) studied the vibrational behavior of bioliquid-filled microtubules embedded in cytoplasm based upon the modified couple stress elasticity theory. Tadi Beni and Karimi Zeverdejani (2015) employed the modified couple stress elasticity theory to the classical shell theory for free vibration analysis of protein microtubules. Wang et al. (2016a) identified the role of inter-protofilament sliding in the bending of microtubules. Zhong et al. (2016) studied the nonlocal size effect on the nonlinear dynamic stability of lipid micro/nano-tubules using incremental harmonic balance method.
3
In order to take small scale effects into consideration with high accuracy, a variety of non-classical continuum theories have been proposed, e.g. nonlocal elasticity theory (Eringen 1972), surface elasticity theory (Gurtin and Murdoch 1978), modified strain gradient elasticity theory (Lam et al. 2003), and modified couple stress elasticity theory (Yang et al. 2002). In recent years, several investigations have been carried out based upon these unconventional theories of elasticity to demonstrate different size effects on mechanical response of micro/nano-structures (Hu et al. 2008; Shen and Zhang 2010; Mohammadi et al. 2014; Li and Hu 2015; Challamel et al. 2016; Yu et al. 2016; Simsek 2016a; Wang et al. 2016b; Tang et al. 2016; Xu et al. 2016; He et al. 2017; Mirsalehi et al. 2017; Sahmani et al. 2017a , b). Recently, Lim et al. (2015) combined the nonlocal and strain gradient elasticity theories in order to add both nonlocality of higher-order stresses and nonlocal higher-order strain gradients. As a result, more reasonable explanation of size dependency in mechanical characteristics of nanostructures has been introduced incorporating two entirely different features of hardening-stiffness and softening-stiffness size effects simultaneously. Lately, some investigations have been carried out based on the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. For instance, Li and Hu (2015) reported the size-dependent critical buckling loads of nonlinear Euler-Bernoulli nanobeams based upon nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity. Li and Hu (2016) also presented the sizedependent frequency of wave motion on fluid-conveying carbon nanotubes via nonlocal strain gradient theory. Yang et al. (2016) established a nonlocal strain gradient beam model to evaluate the critical voltages corresponding to pull-in instability of functionally graded carbon nanotube reinforced actuators at nanoscale. Simsek (2016 b) used nonlocal strain gradient theory to capture the size effects on the nonlinear natural frequencies of functionally graded Euler-Bernoulli nanobeams. Farajpour et al. (2016) proposed a new size-dependent plate model for buckling of orthotropic nanoplates based on nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. Tang et al. (2017) studied the wave propagation in a viscoelastic carbon nanotube via nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. Sahmani and Aghdam (2017a) employed the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory for postbuckling analysis of axially loaded microtubules embedded in the cytoplasm of a living cell. Li et al. (2017) utilized the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory within the framework of the Euler-Bernoulli beam theory to explore bending, buckling and free vibration of axially functionally graded nanobeams. Ebrahimi and Barati (2017a) analyzed the buckling behavior of functionally graded curved nanobeams via the nonlocal strain gradient beam model. Ebrahimi and Barati (2017b) reported the influence the through-thickness temperature variation on nonlocal strain gradient frequencies of axially graded nanobeams. Sahmani and Aghdam (2017b, c) investigated the nonlinear instability of multilayer functionally graded nanoshells under axial compression and hydrostatic pressure on the basis of the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity. Xu et al. (2017) utilized the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory for bending and buckling analyses of Euler-Bernoulli nanobeams. Lu et al. (2017) analyzed the sizedependent free vibration response of shear deformable nanobeams via nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. Ebrahimi and Dabbagh (2017) investigated the nonlocality and strain gradient size
4
dependencies in the wave dispersion characteristics of smart rotating magneto-electro-elastic nanoplates Li and Hu (2017) studied small scale effects on the postbuckling behavior of functionally graded nanobeams on the basis of the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity.
In the previous investigations about mechanical characteristics of the lipid supramolecular micro/nano-tubule, the both of stiffness-hardening and stiffness-softening size effects have not been considered simultaneously. The prime objective of this work is to predict simultaneously the two entirely different size effects on the nonlinear vibrations of axially compressed DC8,9PC lipid micro/nano-tubules within the both prebuckling and postbuckling regimes. To this end, the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory is incorporated in the third-order shear deformable beam model. The non-classical governing differential equations of motion are derived via Hamilton's principle. Afterwards, the Galerkin method together with an improved perturbation technique is utilized to obtain the nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear load-frequency response of prebuckled and postbuckled axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubules.

sections.heading: 2. Nonlocal strain gradient beam model for lipid micro/nano-tubules
sections.text:
In Figure 1, a DC8,9PC lipid micro/nano-tubule created from twisting of bilayer stripe molecules. Due to chirality, the molecules do not pack parallel to each other. The lipid micro/nano-tubule pinned at both ends has a length of , mean radius and thickness . The coordinate system is attached to the lipid tubule in such a way that x-axis is assumed along the tubule longitudinal axis, and z-axis is along tubule thickness.
Based upon the third-order shear deformation beam model, the components of displacement field
along different coordinate directions take the following forms (Reddy 1984)
where and represent the displacement components of the lipid micro/nano-tubule along x-, yand z-axis, respectively. Moreover, is the rotation relevant to the cross section of the lipid tubule at neutral plane normal about y-axis. As a result, the non-zero strain components can be written as
5
in which ,

is the first-order curvature component,
and
are the higher-order curvature components.
It has been reported previously that the size dependency in mechanical behavior of nanostructures has two entirely different effects which may lead to stiffen or soften the structure. Motivated by this fact, Lim et al. (2015) proposed a more comprehensive unconventional continuum theory namely as nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory which contains the both nonlocal and strain gradient size effects simultaneously. As a result, the total nonlocal strain gradient stress tensor for a beam-type structure can be read as below (Lim et al. 2015)
where and in order stand for the stress and higher-order stress tensors which can be expressed as

sections.heading: 4. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Selected numerical results are presented in this section for size-dependent nonlinear vibrational response of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubules within the prebuckling and postbuckling domains. In the current study, the DC8,9PC lipid micro/nano-tubules with four different geometries are analyzed namely as Type-A, Type-B, Type-C, and Type-D. The geometry parameters and material properties corresponding to each type are tabulated in Table 1. Also, all of the lipid micro/nanotubules are supposed as long beams, so for all types, it is assumed that .
Firstly, the validity of the present solution methodology is checked. In accordance with the best authors' knowledge, there is no investigation in which the size-dependent nonlinear vibration of a micro/nano-tubule within postbuckling domain is studied. Therefore, in Table 2, the nonlinear frequency ratio ( ) for an isotropic homogeneous simply supported nanobeam is given and
compared with those presented by Yang et al. (2010) using differential quadrature method. A very good agreement is observed which confirms the validity as well as accuracy of the present solving process.
12
Firstly, in Figure 2, the nonlocal strain gradient postbuckling equilibrium paths of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubule are depicted corresponding to different values of small scale parameters. It can be observed that the nonlocality causes to reduce the critical buckling load, while the strain gradient size dependency leads to enhance it. By moving to deeper part of the postbuckling domain, the gap between equilibrium paths relevant to the various nonlocal parameters increases, but for the strain gradient size effect, this pattern is opposite. In other words, in deeper part of the postbuckling regime, the nonlocality and strain gradient size effects play, respectively, more and less important role in the stability characteristics of an axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubule.
Figure 3 shows the nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear frequency-deflection response of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubules within the both prebuckling ( ) and postbuckling ( ) domains. It is found that by taking the nonlocality into account, the nonlinear frequency of
axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubule corresponding to a specific value of maximum deflection decreases within the both prebuckling and postbuckling regimes. However, for the strain gradient size dependency, this pattern is vice versa, as by taking this type of size effect into consideration, an increment in the value of nonlinear frequency relevant to a specific maximum deflection is seen for prebuckling and postbuckling domains of the axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubule. Additionally, the both kinds of size effect on the nonlinear frequency are more significant at higher maximum deflection which causes to increase the gap between the frequency-deflection curves.
Figures 4 and 5 illustrate, respectively, the influence of nonlocal and strain gradient size effects on the nonlinear frequency-deflection response of different types of axially compressed lipid micro/nanotubules corresponding to prebuckling ( ), buckling ( ) and postbuckling ( ) domains. It is indicated that by changing the type of lipid micro/nano-tubule from Type-A to Type-D (longer lipid tubule), the nonlinear frequency relevant to the prebuckling regime increases and this increment is more considerable at higher maximum deflection. Moreover, in the postbuckling regime, it is demonstrated that by changing the type of lipid micro/nano-tubule from Type-A to Type-D, the slope of nonlinear frequency-deflection curve reduces and the gap between curves is more significant at higher maximum deflection. Furthermore, it can be seen that by taking the nonlocal size effect into consideration, the influence of the type of lipid micro/nano-tubule (geometrical parameters of the lipid tubule) on the nonlinear vibration characteristics within the both prebuckling and postbuckling domains decreases and the frequency-deflection curves are more close to each other. However, the strain gradient size dependency has an opposite effect and leads to increase the gap between the frequency-deflection curves of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubules with different geometrical parameters (various types).
In order to indicate the influence of the small scales effects on the nonlinear vibration response of lipid micro/nano-tubules subjected to a specific value of axial compression, Tables 3 and 4 give, respectfully, the effects of nonlocality and strain gradient size dependency on the nonlinear frequency of the different types of lipid micro/nano-tubules under , , and compressive loads, where
13
represents the classical (size-independent) value of the critical buckling load for each type of the lipid micro/nano-tubule. It is revealed that the significance of the both nonlocal and strain gradient size effects on the nonlinear frequency of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubules reduces through increasing the applied load from to , but enhances through increasing the applied load from
to
. This pattern is the same for all types of the lipid micro/nano-tubule. In addition, it can be
found that for all three cases of the applied compression, the influence of the strain gradient size dependency on the nonlinear frequency is more than that of the nonlocal size effect.
The influence of slenderness ratio ( ) on the size-dependent nonlinear vibration response of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubules is illustrated in Figure 6 corresponding to the prebuckling ( ) and postbuckling ( ) domains. The different values of is selected in such a way that the shear deformation plays an important role (not very long lipid micro/nano-tubules). It is displyaed that by increasing the slenderness ratio (higher value of ), the nonlinear frequency relevant to the prebuckling regime reduces and this reduction is more significant at higher maximum deflection. Moreover, in the postbuckling regime, it is demonstrated that by increasing the value of
, the slope of nonlinear frequency-deflection curve increases and the gap between curves is more
considerable at higher maximum deflection.

sections.heading: 5. Concluding remarks
sections.text:
In the present study, the size-dependent nonlinear vibration response of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubule as a self-assembled structure with a wide range of biological application was investigated corresponding to the prebuckling, buckling, and postbuckling regimes. In order to capture the size dependency in a more comprehensive way including hardening and softening influences simultaneously, the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity was implemented in the third-order shear deformable beam model. After that, the Galerkin method together with an improved perturbation technique was employed to construct explicit analytical expressions for nonlocal strain gradient frequency-deflection path as well as postbuckling equilibrium curves of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubules with various geometrical parameters.
It was found that the nonlocality causes to reduce the critical buckling load, while the strain gradient size dependency leads to enhance it. Also, it was seen that by moving to deeper part of the postbuckling domain, the gap between equilibrium paths relevant to the various nonlocal parameters increases, but for the strain gradient size effect, this pattern is opposite. It was observed that by taking the nonlocality into account, the nonlinear frequency of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubule corresponding to a specific value of maximum deflection decreases within the both prebuckling and postbuckling regimes. However, for the strain gradient size dependency, this pattern is vice versa. Moreover, it was revealed that by taking the nonlocal size effect into consideration, the influence of the type of lipid micro/nano-tubule (geometrical parameters of the lipid tubule) on the nonlinear
14
vibration characteristics within the both prebuckling and postbuckling domains decreases However, the strain gradient size dependency has an opposite effect and leads to increase the gap between the frequency-deflection curves. Furthermore, it was demonstrated that the significance of the both nonlocal and strain gradient size effects on the nonlinear frequency of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubules reduces through increasing the applied load from to , but enhances
through increasing the applied load from to
.

In order to release bioactive agents, Meilander et al. (2001) introduced a lipid-based micro/nano-tubular drug delivery vehicle.

For instance, Rosso and Virga (1998) presented an exact solution for statics and an approximate solution for detachment dynamics of adhering lipid micro/nano-tubules.

2016; Simsek 2016a; Wang et al. 2016b; Tang et al. 2016; Xu et al. 2016; He et al. 2017; Mirsalehi et al. 2017; Sahmani et al. 2017a , b). Recently, Lim et al. (2015) combined the nonlocal and strain gradient elasticity theories in order to add both nonlocality of higher-order stresses and nonlocal higher-order strain gradients.

2016; Simsek 2016a; Wang et al. 2016b; Tang et al. 2016; Xu et al. 2016; He et al. 2017; Mirsalehi et al. 2017; Sahmani et al. 2017a , b). Recently, Lim et al. (2015) combined the nonlocal and strain gradient elasticity theories in order to add both nonlocality of higher-order stresses and nonlocal higher-order strain gradients. As a result, more reasonable explanation of size dependency in mechanical characteristics of nanostructures has been introduced incorporating two entirely different features of hardening-stiffness and softening-stiffness size effects simultaneously. Lately, some investigations have been carried out based on the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. For instance, Li and Hu (2015) reported the size-dependent critical buckling loads of nonlinear Euler-Bernoulli nanobeams based upon nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity.

As a result, the total nonlocal strain gradient stress tensor for a beam-type structure can be read as below (Lim et al. 2015)

Motivated by this fact, Lim et al. (2015) proposed a more comprehensive unconventional continuum theory namely as nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory which contains the both nonlocal and strain gradient size effects simultaneously.

metadata.abstractText: The unique geometry with high surface ratio makes lipid micro/nano-tubules as an excellent selfassembled supramolecular structure in various biological applications such as controllable release systems and drug delivery. In the present study, the size-dependent nonlinear vibrations of axially loaded lipid micro/nano tubules associated with the both prebuckling and postbuckling domains are explored comprehensively. To accomplish this purpose, the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity including simultaneously two entirely different features of size dependency is utilized within the framework of the third-order shear deformable beam model. With the aid of Hamilton's principle, the non-classical governing differential equations of motion are established incorporating the nonlinear prebuckling deformations and the large postbuckling deflections. At the end, the Galerkin method in conjunction with an improved perturbation technique is employed to initiate explicit analytical expressions for nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear frequency of preand post-buckled lipid micro/nano-tubules. It is seen that by taking the nonlocal size effect into consideration, the influence of geometrical parameters of the lipid micro/nano-tubule on the nonlinear vibration characteristics within the both prebuckling and postbuckling domains decreases and the frequency-deflection curves are more close to each other. However, the strain gradient size dependency has an opposite effect and leads to increase the gap between the frequency-deflection curves of axially compressed lipid micro/nano-tubules with different geometrical parameters.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
